captions.text:
This time we'll be taking a look at the title
screen secrets of Mairo Paint for the Super
Nintendo

Now as you may already know, Mario Paint isn't
really a game at all. Instead, it was more

of a tool for creating all-kinds of digital
artwork, but what made it stand-out was its
sense of fun.

And that fun begins right away on the title-screen,
where Mario darts around and even shows-off
a few of his moves

Now normally, you'd simply use the cursor
to click on Mario and start the game.

But if you take some time to explore, you
might find that the Mario Paint title there

isn't there for just looks, as every one of
the letter causes something unique to happen
if you click on it.

Take "M" for example, which causes Mario to
shrink, as if he got hit by an enemy. But

don't worry, you can fix him right back up
by clicking on it again, just as if he got
a power-up

Then there's the first "A," which straight-up
just drops away before returning a few seconds

later. However, if you time it just right,
it'll take Mario with it too. Poor guy didn't
even see it coming!

Clicking on "R" causes it to make a weird
baby-like sound while growing an eye and walking
around/ Yeah, that one's a bit strange.

But check out what happens if we take that
same baby sound and play it backwards at half
the speed
Yup, it's some dude saying Nintendo--weird

The first "I" briefly inverts many of the
colors causing Mario to look like an old man,
while making the music sound a little weird.

If you're looking for a little more action,
try clicking on the O to turn it into a bomb

which soon explodes, temporarily taking all
of the letters on-screen with it.

But that's not all, because listen to what
happens next...

What you just heard is actually what's known
as Totaka's Song, a simple 19-note melody

hidden by the game's composer Kazumi Totaka
in most of the game's he's worked on. And

his is actually one of its earliest appearances,
which is pretty cool.

Next up is "P," which causes a nice little
landscape to appear set to a bounce little

tune.. And it's populated by all kinds of
objects that make between 1-3 unique sounds

when you click on them like flowers, cars,
trains, dogs, planes, and even UFOs

But every once in a while, you'll see a shooting
star too. And if you're quick enough, you

can even click on it too, which will cause
a ton of objects to rain down in the background,
as well as making a weird harp sound

Now after "P" we have the second "A," which
causes Yoshi to run across the screen, complete

with a percussion track that's added to the
music , just like when you rode him in Super
Mario World

Next up is the second "I," which causes all
the text to wobble, while giving the music
a wobbly feel too

Alright, we're getting close to the end, so
it's perhaps fitting that "N" causes the credits

to appear, and it too causes an extra drum
line to be added to the music, which is a
nice touch.

But the Credits sequence hides another secret.
When you see the programmer Noriaki Teramoto

appear, hold down the right mouse button,
then click the Letter "N" again to turn off

the credits. Now when you start the game,
you'll have access to several new features.

These include right-clicking to undo, right-clicking
to select the highlighted color in the Stamp

Editor, as well unlocking four new rotations
for the stamps. Pretty crazy, huh?

Finally, there's "T" which changes makes the
music a little slower and laid-back, while

changing the cursor into a pen that allows
you to draw all over the title screen with
colorful lines.

See, you don't even have to start the game
proper to begin your career as an artirst

And speaking of starting the game, there's
still one more secret left.

When you're finally done playing around, you'll
probably want to click on Mario to actually
get started. And here's what normally happens.

Yep, the game even treats you to a short intro
movie before sending you off on your own,
which is pretty cool by itself

But every once in while, you'll get a version
that's just a little different. Check it out.

It's pretty clear a lot of creativity was
put into Mario Paint' title screen, which

is a perfect fit for a game based entirely
around being creative.

And that wraps up this episode of Cool Bits
for Mario Paint. Now let us know if you have

any Cool Bits of your own by posting in the
comments and we may feature it in a future
episode.

Thanks for watching and make sure to stay-tuned
to GameXplain.com for more Cool Bits and everything
gaming

title: Cool Bits - Mario Paint's Title Screen Secrets & Code (+Totaka's Song)
